channel.title: NPR Topics: News
channel.description: NPR news, audio, and podcasts. Coverage of breaking stories, national and world news, politics, business, science, technology, and extended coverage of major national and world events.
channel.copyright: Copyright 2024 NPR - For Personal Use Only

item.title: Max Frankel, former New York Times top editor, dies at 94
item.description: Frankel was The New York Times' executive editor from 1986 to 1994. He remained with the newspaper for nearly half a century, ushering it through different eras.
item.content:encoded:
Frankel was The New York Times' executive editor from 1986 to 1994. He remained with the newspaper for nearly half a century, ushering it through different eras.

(Image credit: ‎)
item.dc:creator: Jordan-Marie Smith

item.title: Venezuela says it will start accepting repatriation flights from the U.S. again
item.description: Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has called for the return of the Venezuelan migrants sent by the U.S. to El Salvador, where President Nayib Bukele said they were transferred to a mega-prison.
item.content:encoded:
Venezuelan President Nicolás Maduro has called for the return of the Venezuelan migrants sent by the U.S. to El Salvador, where President Nayib Bukele said they were transferred to a mega-prison.

(Image credit: Javier Campos)
item.dc:creator: Joe Hernandez

item.title: How an obscure legal theory shaped the immunity decision and Trump's second term
item.description:
In Trump v. United States, the Supreme Court held that the president has "absolute immunity from criminal prosecution" for official acts.

To reach that conclusion, the High Court grappled with this question: how much power a president should have?

And some legal scholars say the ruling draws on the unitary executive theory — which, in its most extreme interpretation, gives the president sole authority over the executive branch.

But did it pave the way for Trump's second term and the constitutional questions it's raised: From the dismantling of federal agencies established by Congress to the deportation migrants to third party countries without due process?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.
item.content:encoded:
In Trump v. United States, the Supreme Court held that the president has "absolute immunity from criminal prosecution" for official acts.

To reach that conclusion, the High Court grappled with this question: how much power a president should have?

And some legal scholars say the ruling draws on the unitary executive theory — which, in its most extreme interpretation, gives the president sole authority over the executive branch.

But did it pave the way for Trump's second term and the constitutional questions it's raised: From the dismantling of federal agencies established by Congress to the deportation migrants to third party countries without due process?

For sponsor-free episodes of Consider This, sign up for Consider This+ via Apple Podcasts or at plus.npr.org.

Email us at considerthis@npr.org.

(Image credit: MANDEL NGAN)

item.title: Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney and opponent kick off their election campaigns
item.description: Trump's frequent attacks on Canada's sovereignty have infuriated Canadians and led to a surge in Canadian nationalism that has bolstered Liberal poll numbers.
item.content:encoded:
Trump's frequent attacks on Canada's sovereignty have infuriated Canadians and led to a surge in Canadian nationalism that has bolstered Liberal poll numbers.

(Image credit: Sean Kilpatrick)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press

item.title: Pope Francis is discharged from the hospital after treatment for respiratory infection
item.description: The pontiff left the hospital on Sunday following treatment for a severe respiratory infection that led to bilateral pneumonia.
item.content:encoded:
The pontiff left the hospital on Sunday following treatment for a severe respiratory infection that led to bilateral pneumonia.

(Image credit: Domenico Stinellis)
item.dc:creator: Ruth Sherlock

item.title: Palestinian deaths in Gaza rise above 50,000 as Israel expands its military campaign
item.description: The death toll reached the milestone just days after Israel resumed its military campaign in Gaza, breaking a ceasefire with Hamas.
item.content:encoded:
The death toll reached the milestone just days after Israel resumed its military campaign in Gaza, breaking a ceasefire with Hamas.

(Image credit: Jehad Alshrafi)
item.dc:creator: Hadeel Al-Shalchi

item.title: This Harlem pastor fights mental health stigma — and shares his own struggles
item.description: First Corinthian Baptist Church founded a separate nonprofit that employs therapists to bring mental health care to a community where stigma remains a high barrier to healing.
item.content:encoded:
First Corinthian Baptist Church founded a separate nonprofit that employs therapists to bring mental health care to a community where stigma remains a high barrier to healing.

(Image credit: José A. Alvarado Jr. for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Katia Riddle

item.title: As Ovechkin nears the NHL goals record, the hockey world leans in to savor the moment
item.description: For years, Wayne Gretzky's record of 894 career regular-season goals was widely thought to be untouchable. Now, the Washington Capitals star has just a handful to go to claim the record as his own.
item.content:encoded:
For years, Wayne Gretzky's record of 894 career regular-season goals was widely thought to be untouchable. Now, the Washington Capitals star has just a handful to go to claim the record as his own.

(Image credit: Bruce Bennett)
item.dc:creator: Becky Sullivan

item.title: Humming along in an old church, the Internet Archive is more relevant than ever
item.description: The Trump administration's erasure of federal data has put the Internet Archive in the spotlight. The organization, with its small but mighty team, is working to help save the world's digital history.
item.content:encoded:
The Trump administration's erasure of federal data has put the Internet Archive in the spotlight. The organization, with its small but mighty team, is working to help save the world's digital history.

(Image credit: Carolyn Fong for NPR)
item.dc:creator: Emma Bowman

item.title: Israeli strikes on Gaza kill 26, including Hamas official
item.description: Israeli strikes across the southern Gaza Strip killed at least 26 Palestinians overnight, including a Hamas political leader, as the military ordered new evacuations in the southern city of Rafah.
item.content:encoded:
Israeli strikes across the southern Gaza Strip killed at least 26 Palestinians overnight, including a Hamas political leader, as the military ordered new evacuations in the southern city of Rafah.

(Image credit: Ohad Zwigenberg)
item.dc:creator: The Associated Press
